[Statement 1]: Based on available evidence, cutting/mowing appears to be a commonly studied and effective method for controlling problematic plants on peatlands.
[Statement 2]: Cutting/mowing problematic herbaceous plants typically had no significant effect on overall plant community composition.
[Statement 3]: Cutting/mowing problematic herbaceous plants increased fen-characteristic plant species.
[Statement 4]: Cutting/mowing problematic herbaceous plants had mixed effects on vegetation cover in fens.
[Statement 5]: Cutting/mowing to maintain or restore disturbance altered plant community composition.
[Statement 6]: Cutting/mowing to maintain or restore disturbance increased the cover of fen- or wet meadow-characteristic plants.
[Statement 7]: Cutting/mowing to maintain or restore disturbance increased moss cover.
[Statement 8]: Cutting/mowing reduced the cover of problematic herbs including reeds, sedges, and purple moor grass.
[Statement 9]: The timing of cutting/mowing could influence the effectiveness of the method.
[Statement 10]: Summer mowing increased plant species richness more than spring or autumn mowing.
[Statement 11]: Herbicide application showed mixed results for controlling problematic plants on peatlands.
[Statement 12]: Herbicide application changed plant community composition.
[Statement 13]: Herbicide application failed to prevent increases in shrub cover over time.
[Statement 14]: Biological control through introducing organisms showed promise in one study.
[Statement 15]: In one study, introducing a parasitic plant reduced dominant sedge cover.
[Statement 16]: In one study, introducing a parasitic plant increased plant species richness.
[Statement 17]: No studies were found evaluating covers or barriers for cost-effectiveness or effectiveness on peatlands.
[Statement 18]: No studies were found evaluating physical damage methods for cost-effectiveness or effectiveness on peatlands.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the most cost-effective way to control problematic plants on peatlands?
